questions.question_text: In which of the following categories does a business process change fit?

discussion.content: Departmental change is the internal portion of Organizational Change or better said, part of a Re-Org.
I don't think Departmental change exist

choices.C: Version control processes were not applied.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Are these questions based on an assumption that the program manager contacted CCB and the change was approved, and after that, the project manager updated the shared document? If yes, then, the answer C is correct. The issue arose due to the version control.

comments.content: That's a fair answer as well.

not contacting the CCB wouldn't be why it failed a municipal code audit. More likely is some documentation was not properly updated resulting in the old version of the deliverable being produced. So version control is a possible answer, I'm not totally convinced myself though, but I think we can rule out CCB.

discussion.content: Shouln't the answer be D. The CCB was not contacted?

questions.question_text:
A change must be made to a project to comply with municipal code. The project manager updates the relevant shared project documents. The key stakeholders subsequently update the documents with new information. When the project deliverables are reinspected, they fail the inspection. Which of the following is the
MOST likely reason for the failed inspection?

choices.D: The reduced budget will cause the project manager to reject the change order.
choices.C: The reduced timeline will decrease risk, resulting in an increased contingency reserve.
choices.B: The reduced budget will result in reduced resources, which will lead to a strong matrix organizational structure being used.
choices.A: The reduced timeline will impact the quality of the deliverables because the amount of time to test will be reduced.

discussion.content: I feel this should be A. A reduced timeline/budget but we have to keep the same deliverables, would mean to me that we would risk having a lower quality product.

B says "which will lead to a strong matrix organizational structure being used." You don't lead to a strong matrix, your organization either is a matrix, functional or projectized. You don't suddenly turn into a strong matrix organization. The most logical explanation here is A.

comments.content: If you think a PM has the clout to change the fundamental power structure of an organization, good luck with that!

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
I agree with most comments. You don't just change into a different org structure. Think "Good, fast, cheap - choose two". You just chose fast and cheap in the first sentence.
These questions literally make no sense. A. has to be the correct answer here.

Selected Answer: A
Most logically we will think of the triple constraints here - time reduced; quality affected

"deliverables of the project must remain unchanged"

I would jump on A if this statement wasn't in the question.

A catch 22 to me.. if you reduce budget and time it is only logical to assume the deliverable will be of lower quality.

But, as mentioned I will go for B

comments.content:
I agree with anthonyyo... you dont suddenly turn into a strong matrix.. so the answer A makes more sense.
@Ayoyemi-- can you explain what makes you think B is the correct answer

discussion.content: Correct Answer is B

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities are associated with the closing phase of a project? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Not only is it time-sensitive but also critical, which means confidential/important so social media, texting and online web content will not be valid answers. 
One-on-one is the least horrible choice.

Its A. I feel this is a technical question but easily distinguishable. Poor sound quality during calls is due to bad connection. With this being said, internet is the problem... Project wiki, text messages, and social media all rely on the internet. So one-on-one meetings regardless of the speed, are more effective than any communication online. Also, they type of communication needs to be considered. How do I know for a fact you received the information as I relayed it to you with out hearing a response or seeing your body expressions in person? Text, social media and wiki are all things some old head without a phone wouldn't actively participate in.

Text messages are for individual communication, Project wiki isnt anywhere near any study materials I can find and social media, what if someone isnt actively online? One-on-One meets are not only singular person meetings and there is no mention of people located across multiple locations...

Selected Answer: C
Agreed, one-on-one meetings would not be time-sensitive and possibly not geographically possible.

Terrible question. Time sensitive means this needs to happen quickly. One on one meetings may or may not be able to happen quickly depending on where the team members are located. Text messages are not designed for conference sized audiences nor critical information that may require a lot of back and forth with questions. Social media is also not ideal considering a lot of this material may not be something you want floating around on the internet. I think a virtual conference would be better.

This one is tough, I've been on a lot of conference calls even emergency ones and I can't really imagine many of them being carried out via a group text message, but one on one meetings can only work if the entire team is in the immediate vicinity which isn't specified.

I disagree with both A and C being the answers, text messaging is used for short, quick, and easy communication which does fit the criteria of critical and time-sensitive, however, it doesn't fit to have a group text sent to a conference call size audience. When I think of critical conference calls I think of complex information that needs to be distributed, far more than can be appropriate to text on a phone. If the PM doesn't opt for group texts and opts for one-on-one texts, then it may as well be option A. To me, the logical means of communication would be D, Social Media, which allows for interaction and communication on a large-scale, content sharing and ability to access it from anywhere.
One-on-one meeting cannot possibly substitute for a CONFERENCE call, which is time sensitive. Group text message it is!

The questions states "time-sensitive" calls.
One-on-one can not be carried out always immediately.
For these reasons, C is the correct answer.
A. Correct answer
